text: <https://twitter.com/owainkenway/status/1371892950016389135> when will we have this for Julia? :sob:  the fact that works also in markdown files is very cool

attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/owainkenway|@owainkenway>: This is a pretty neat feature of Github - with Python it not only syntax highlight's code in markdown documents, it reads imported modules and can tell you where the symbol was defined. <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/EwnxLXaWQAMjPSf.jpg>
attachments.text: This is a pretty neat feature of Github - with Python it not only syntax highlight's code in markdown documents, it reads imported modules and can tell you where the symbol was defined. <https://pbs.twimg.com/media/EwnxLXaWQAMjPSf.jpg>

elements.text: when will we have this for Julia?
the fact that works also in markdown files is very cool

text: I wonder if that's implemented via LS or some other static analysis

text: Yeah thatd be so nice! Sometimes I want to easily go to a function definition on github and I resort to CTRL+F on each file

text: yeah, I think they do static analysis.  I knew this in the code, I discovered with this tweet it works even in the README

text: I'm hand writing an incremental parser right now.. It is one of the least fun things I've ever personally done...

text: This update made reading other peoples work so much easier for me. Its really easy to get lost in code, especially when its not yours
